```{ojs}
md`# Decaliper`
```

```{ojs}
md`This [notebook](/@dec/alc) demonstrates how Dec, a measurement system [I](https://maptv.github.io) created, [measures angles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angle#Measuring_angles) in [turns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turn_%28angle%29#:~:text=a%20unit%20of%20plane%20angle%20measurement%20equal%20to%202%CF%80%C2%A0radians%2C%20360%C2%A0degrees) ([${tex`\tau`}](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turn_%28angle%29#:~:text=the%20Greek%20letter,to%20one%20turn)) instead of [degrees](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degree_%28angle%29#:~:text=a%20measurement%20of%20a%20plane%20angle%20in%20which%20one%20full%20rotation%20is%20360%20degrees) (°), [arcminutes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minute_and_second_of_arc#:~:text=one%20arcminute%20is,of%20a%20turn) (′), and [arcseconds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minute_and_second_of_arc#:~:text=degree%2C%5B1%5D-,1,of%20a%20turn,-%2C%20and) (″). Use the slider beneath the yellow car below to steer the car away from its initial northward [heading](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heading_%28navigation%29#:~:text=the%20compass%20direction%20in%20which%20the%20craft%27s%20bow%20or%20nose%20is%20pointed). The compass below the slider shows the car's current heading, while the clock below the compass displays the [bearing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bearing_%28navigation%29#Relative:~:text=the%20angle%20between%20the%20craft%27s%20forward%20direction%20%28heading%29%20and%20the%20location%20of%20another%20object) relative to the car's heading, or in other words the [clock position](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clock_position#:~:text=a%20system%20of%20denoting%20impromptu%20relative%20bearing%20widely%20used%20in%20practical%20navigation%20to%20give%20the%20position%20of%20an%20observed%20object), of the person to right of the car.`
```

```{ojs}
// https://observablehq.com/@d3/simple-clock
// https://observablehq.com/@drio/lets-build-an-analog-clock
clockPositionClock = {
  const clockRadius = 200,
    margin = 50,
    w = (clockRadius + margin) * 2,
    h = (clockRadius + margin) * 2,
    hourHandLength = (2 * clockRadius) / 3,
    minuteHandLength = clockRadius,
    secondHandLength = clockRadius - 12,
    secondHandBalance = 30,
    secondTickStart = clockRadius,
    secondTickLength = -10,
    hourTickStart = clockRadius,
    hourTickLength = -18,
    secondLabelRadius = clockRadius + 16,
    secondLabelYOffset = 5,
    hourLabelRadius = clockRadius - 40,
    hourLabelYOffset = 7,
    radians = Math.PI / 180;

  const ten = d3
    .scaleLinear()
    .range([0, 360])
    .domain([0, 10]);

  const sto = d3
    .scaleLinear()
    .range([0, 360])
    .domain([0, 100]);

  const handData = [
    {
      type: "hour",
      value: 0,
      length: -hourHandLength,
      scale: ten
    },
  ];

  function drawClock() {
    // create all the clock elements
    updateData(); //draw them in the correct starting position
    const face = svg
      .append("g")
      .attr("id", "clock-face")
      .attr("transform", `translate(${[w / 2, h / 2]})`);

    // add marks for seconds
    face
      .selectAll(".second-tick")
      .data(d3.range(0, 100))
      .enter()
      .append("line")
      .attr("class", "second-tick")
      .attr("x1", 0)
      .attr("x2", 0)
      .attr("y1", secondTickStart)
      .attr("y2", secondTickStart + secondTickLength)
      .attr("transform", d => `rotate(${sto(d)})`);

    // ... and hours
    face
      .selectAll(".hour-tick")
      .data(d3.range(0, 10, 1))
      .enter()
      .append("line")
      .attr("class", "hour-tick")
      .attr("x1", 0)
      .attr("x2", 0)
      .attr("y1", hourTickStart)
      .attr("y2", hourTickStart + hourTickLength)
      .attr("transform", d => `rotate(${ten(d)})`);

    face
      .selectAll(".hour-label")
      .data(d3.range(0, 10, 1))
      .enter()
      .append("text")
      .attr("class", "hour-label")
      .attr("text-anchor", "middle")
      .attr("x", d => hourLabelRadius * Math.sin(ten(d) * radians))
      .attr(
        "y",
        d => -hourLabelRadius * Math.cos(ten(d) * radians) + hourLabelYOffset
      )
      .text(d => d);

    const hands = face.append("g").attr("id", "clock-hands");

    hands
      .selectAll("line")
      .data(handData)
      .enter()
      .append("line")
      .attr("class", d => d.type + "-hand")
      .attr("x1", 0)
      .attr("y1", d => d.balance || 0)
      .attr("x2", 0)
      .attr("y2", d => d.length)
      .attr("transform", d => `rotate(${d.scale(d.value)})`);

    face
      .append("g")
      .attr("id", "face-overlay")
      .append("circle")
      .attr("class", "hands-cover")
      .attr("x", 0)
      .attr("y", 0)
      .attr("r", clockRadius / 20);
  }

  function moveHands() {
    const sel = d3
      .select("#clock-hands-final")
      .selectAll("line")
      .data(handData)
      .transition();

  }
  
function unix2dote(unix, zone, offset = 719468) {
  return [
    (unix ?? Date.now()) / 86400000
    + (zone = zone ?? (10 - Math.round(
        (new Date).getTimezoneOffset() / 144)) % 10
      ) / 10 + offset, zone]
}
  

  function updateData() {
    const unix = Date.now();
    handData[0].value = clockPosition / 100;
  }

  const svg = d3
    .create("svg")
    .attr("viewBox", [0, 0, w, h])
    .style("max-width", "350px")
    .style("margin-bottom", "-51px")
    .attr("id", "clock");


  svg
    .append("text")
    .text(`Heading: ${(milliturns + 1000) % 1000}`)
    .attr("x", 100)
    .attr("y", margin)
    .attr("text-anchor", "middle")
    .attr("font-size", 23)
    .attr("font-family", "monospace");
  
  svg
    .append("text")
    .text(`Bearing: ${clockPosition}`)
    .attr("x", 400)
    .attr("y", margin)
    .attr("text-anchor", "middle")
    .attr("font-size", 23)
    .attr("font-family", "monospace");
  
  drawClock();

  // Animation
  const interval = setInterval(
    () => {
      updateData();
      moveHands();
    },
    864
  );
  invalidation.then(() => clearInterval(interval));
  
  return svg.node();
}
```

```{ojs}
md`Even though turns can be combined with any of the various [metric prefixes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metric_prefix#:~:text=a%20unit%20prefix%20that%20precedes%20a%20basic%20unit%20of%20measure%20to%20indicate%20a%20multiple%20or%20submultiple%20of%20the%20unit), [milliturns](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turn_%28angle%29#:~:text=g.%2C%20centiturns%20%28ctr%29%2C-,milliturns,-%28mtr%29%2C%20etc.) (thousandths of a turn) are the most common turn [submultiple](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiple_%28mathematics%29#Submultiple:~:text=of%20%22a%20being-,a%20unit%20fraction,-of%20b%22%20) used by Dec. All of the numbers above are milliturns, except the clock labels, which are deciturns (tenths of a turn). Milliturns are ${tex`2.\overline7`} times more precise than degrees and work well for many different Dec measurements, whereas deciturns are typically only used as single-digit [indexes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Array_%28data_structure%29#Element_identifier_and_addressing_formulas:~:text=When%20data%20objects%20are%20stored%20in%20an%20array%2C%20individual%20objects%20are%20selected%20by%20an%20index) for arrays of 10 items, like Dec [time zones](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_zone#:~:text=an%20area%20which%20observes%20a%20uniform%20standard%20time).`
```

```{ojs}
md`Decidays are also useful describing locations and directions in terms of their [clock positions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clock_position#:~:text=a%20system%20of%20denoting%20impromptu%20relative%20bearing%20widely%20used%20in%20practical%20navigation%20to%20give%20the%20position%20of%20an%20observed%20object). For example, "check your 5" is a warning about something behind you, whereas "head to my 3" is an instruction to go in the direction that is 3 clockwise deciturns from my perspective. Clock positions typically do not have to be very precise and thus double-digit centiturns numbers will most often not be necessary. Instead of "25" and "75", we can say right (25) and left (75) for [body-relative directions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Body_relative_direction#:~:text=geometrical%20orientations%20relative%20to%20a%20body), or [starboard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_and_starboard#:~:text=facing%20the%20bow%2C%20towards%20the%20direction%20the%20vehicle%20is%20heading%20when%20underway.%20the%20starboard%20side%20is%20thus%20to%20the%20right) (25) and [port](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_and_starboard#:~:text=the%20side%20to%20the%20left%20of%20an%20observer%20aboard%20the%20vessel%20and%20facing%20the%20bow%2C%20towards%20the%20direction%20the%20vehicle%20is%20heading%20when%20underway) (75) for vehicle-relative directions.`
```

```{ojs}
md`The slider above allows us to turn the yellow car left or right, i.e. modify its [yaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yaw_%28rotation%29#:~:text=a%20movement%20around%20the%20yaw%20axis%20of%20a%20rigid%20body%20that%20changes%20the%20direction%20it%20is%20pointing%2C%20to%20the%20left%20or%20right%20of%20its%20direction%20of%20motion), with a [turn radius](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turning_radius#:~:text=a%20theoretical%20minimal%20circle%20in%20which%20for%20example%20an%20aeroplane%2C%20a%20ground%20vehicle%20or%20a%20watercraft%20can%20be%20turned%20around) of zero, but typical cars cannot turn around in place, i.e. without moving forward or backward. With a turning radius ${tex`r`} greater than zero (${tex`r\gt0`}), the distance travelled during a full turn is ${tex`\tau r`}, where ${tex`\tau=2\pi`}. At a velocity ${tex`v`} that is greater than 0, the time to complete a full turn is ${tex`\tau r \over v`} and the yaw rate ([angular velocity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angular_velocity#:~:text=how%20quickly%20an%20object%20rotates%20%28spins%20or%20revolves%29%20around%20an%20axis%20of%20rotation)) is ${tex`v \over r`}.`
```

```{ojs}
md`To make a full turn with an ${tex`r`} of [5.41 meters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turning_radius#:~:text=a%20%22curb%2Dto%2Dcurb%20turning%20circle%22%20of%20a%202008%20Cadillac%20CTS%20as%2010.82%20metres) in 4 beats (.004% of a day), we would travel 34 meters at a ${tex`v`} of 8.5 meters per beat (m/b) and turn at a yaw rate of .25 turns per beat. A beat is a centimilliday (0.001% of a day) and is similar in duration to a heartbeat or a musical beat. Kilometers per [centiday](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decimal_time#:~:text=dividing%20the%20day%20into%2010%20decidays%20and%20100%20centidays) are equivalent to m/b.`
```

```{ojs}
md`Speeds in m/b are very intuitive. People [walk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orders_of_magnitude_%28speed%29#:~:text=Average%20walking%20speed) at a speed of [~](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tilde#:~:text=it%20means%20%22approximately%22%2C%20%22about%22%2C%20or%20%22around%22)1 m/b and [ride a bike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orders_of_magnitude_%28speed%29#:~:text=Comfortable%20bicycling%20speed) at about ~5 or ~6 m/b. The world records for [freestyle swimming 50m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_world_records_in_swimming#:~:text=in%20any%20order.-,Freestyle%3A%2050m,-%2C%20100m%2C), [running 42195m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marathon#:~:text=a%20long%2Ddistance%20foot%20race%20with%20a%20distance%20of%2042.195%C2%A0km), and [sprinting 100m](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/100_metres#:~:text=a%20sprint%20race%20in%20track%20and%20field%20competitions) are ~[2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orders_of_magnitude_%28speed%29#:~:text=World%20record%20time%2050m%20freestyle%20swim), ~[5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orders_of_magnitude_%28speed%29#:~:text=World%20record%20time%20marathon), and ~[9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orders_of_magnitude_%28speed%29#:~:text=Top%20speed%20reached%20by%20Bolt) m/b, respectively. [Residential speed limits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orders_of_magnitude_%28speed%29#:~:text=Typical%20residential%20speed%20limit) range from ~6 to ~12 m/b. The top speed of the [world's fastest train service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-speed_rail#:~:text=fastest%20high%2Dspeed%20service%20in%20the%20world) is ~[103 m/b](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High-speed_rail#:~:text=top%20speed%20of-,431%C2%A0km/h%20%28268%C2%A0mph%29,-%2C%20and%20remains%20the). The map below shows each country's highest speed limit in [km/h](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilometres_per_hour#:~:text=the%20number%20of%20kilometres%20travelled%20in%20one%20hour) (red circles), [mph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miles_per_hour#:~:text=the%20number%20of%20miles%20travelled%20in%20one%20hour) (rectangles with rounded edges), and m/b (red decagons).`
```

```{ojs}
md`Unlike typical cars, [quadcopter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadcopter#:~:text=a%20type%20of%20helicopter%20or%20multicopter%20that%20has%20four%20rotors) drones can change yaw without the need for forward or backward motion. The movement of drones and other [radio-controlled aircraft](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio-controlled_aircraft#:~:text=a%20small%20flying%20machine%20that%20is%20radio%20controlled%20by%20an%20operator%20on%20the%20ground%20using%20a%20hand%2Dheld%20radio%20transmitter) along the 3 [principal aircraft axes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_principal_axes#:~:text=An%20aircraft%20in%20flight%20is,running%20from%20nose%20to%20tail.) ([yaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_principal_axes#:~:text=an%20axis%20drawn%20from%20top%20to%20bottom), [pitch](https://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitch,_yaw,_and_roll#:~:text=pitch-,nose%20up%20or%20tail%20up,-.), and [roll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degrees_of_freedom_%28mechanics%29#:~:text=Roll%20rotation%3A-,Pivots%20side%20to%20side,-%3B)) is usually controlled by a remote control [radio transmitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio-controlled_aircraft#/media/File:RC_Transmitter.jpg) with two [analog sticks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analog_stick#:~:text=an%20input%20device%20for%20a%20controller). The [dimensions of movement](https://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitch,_yaw,_and_roll#:~:text=Pitch%2C%20yaw%20and%20roll%20are%20the%20three%20dimensions%20of%20movement) controlled by each stick depends on the [radio transmitter mode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio-controlled_helicopter#:~:text=Mode%201%20%E2%80%93%20the%20left,pitch%20and%20yaw%20movements.).`
```

```{ojs}
md`The names of the modes, `pytr`, `typr`, `prty`, and `trpy`, are based on the movement dimensions assigned to each analog stick. In the default mode, `typr`, the left stick controls throttle and the yaw rate, while the right stick sets pitch and roll. Throttle is velocity along the [z-axis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_principal_axes#:~:text=an%20axis%20drawn%20from%20top%20to%20bottom), while yaw rate is the angular velocity around the z-axis. Pitch and roll are angles of rotation around the [x](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aircraft_principal_axes#Transverse_axis_%28pitch%29:~:text=from%20wingtip%20to%20wingtip) and [y](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitudinal_axis#:~:text=nose%20to%20tail%20of%20a%20plane) axes, respectively.
`
```

```{ojs}
md`While `typr` is the most common mode, the other modes are valid alternatives. Both `typr` and `prty` put pitch and roll together, so that the left (`prty`) or right (`typr`) analog stick behaves like the [center stick](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centre_stick#:~:text=an%20aircraft%20cockpit%20arrangement%20where%20the%20control%20column%20%28or%20joystick%29%20is%20located%20in%20the%20center%20of%20the%20cockpit) in an airplane. In contrast, `pytr` and `trpy` combine pitch and yaw so the the left (`pytr`) or right (`trpy`) analog stick functions like computer keyboard [arrow keys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arrow_keys#:~:text=keys%20on%20a%20computer%20keyboard%20that%20are%20either%20programmed%20or%20designated%20to%20move%20the%20cursor%20in%20a%20specified%20direction) or a [video game controller](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamepad#:~:text=a%20type%20of%20video%20game%20controller%20held%20in%20two%20hands) [d-pad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D-pad#:~:text=a%20flat%2C%20typically%20thumb%2Doperated%2C%20directional%20control).`
```

```{ojs}
md`You can try out all 4 modes in the drone piloting example below. Select a mode using the radio button below. Adjust the drone's yaw and [altitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Altitude#:~:text=a%20distance%20measurement%2C%20usually%20in%20the%20vertical%20or%20%22up%22%20direction) using the two one-dimensional (1D) slider beneath the radio buttons. Yaw is measured in milliturns and altitude is measured in [per mille](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Per_mille#:~:text=%5B1%5D%20indicates-,parts%20per%20thousand.,-%5B2%5D%20The) (‰) change from the starting altitude (0). Both yaw and altitude have the same range (${tex`-1000 \lt x \lt 1000`}).`
```

```{ojs}
md`Beneath the 1D sliders, there is a pair of two-dimensional (2D) sliders and 4 views of the drone: top, side, front, and rear. Move the 2D sliders like remote control radio transmitter analog sticks and observe the drone's yaw in the top view, pitch in the side view, and roll in the front and rear views. To give a sense of throttle, the top view zooms in and out while the other views scroll the background vertically.`
```

You can use the sliders below to rotate the map beneath the sliders. `

```{ojs}
md`Just like [geographic coordinates](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system#Latitude_and_longitude:~:text=a%20spherical%20or%20geodetic%20coordinate%20system%20for%20measuring%20and%20communicating%20positions%20directly%20on%20Earth%20as%20latitude%20and%20longitude), Dec can also be used for other coordinate systems, such as [astronomical coordinate systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_coordinate_systems#:~:text=coordinate%20systems%20are%20used%20for%20specifying%20positions%20of%20celestial%20objects) which have analogs of [longitude and latitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_coordinate_systems#:~:text=%280%C2%B0%20longitude%29-,Latitude,Longitude,-Horizontal%20%28also%20called). All such coordinates are angles and thus can (and should😄) be measured in turns. Measuring all angles in turns highlights how these measurements are connected.`
```

```{ojs}
md`Increasing longitude, or an analog of longitude in an astronomical coordinate system, until we arrive back at the same point simulates 1 turn of the Earth on [its axis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axial_tilt#:~:text=the%20imaginary%20line%20that%20passes%20through%20both%20the%20north%20pole%20and%20south%20pole). In 1 [solar day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_time#:~:text=the%20interval%20between%20two%20successive%20returns%20of%20the%20sun%20to%20the%20local%20meridian), thanks to the Earth’s rotation on its axis, the Sun completes 1 turn
- across the Earth's surface parallel to the [Equator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equator#:~:text=a%20circle%20of%20latitude%20that%20divides%20a%20spheroid%2C%20such%20as%20Earth%2C%20into%20the%20Northern%20and%20Southern%20hemispheres) ([longitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitude#:~:text=a%20geographic%20coordinate%20that%20specifies%20the%20east%E2%80%93west%20position%20of%20a%20point%20on%20the%20surface%20of%20the%20Earth%2C%20or%20another%20celestial%20body)),
- along the horizon around an observer on Earth ([azimuth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azimuth#:~:text=the%20horizontal%20angle%20from%20a%20cardinal%20direction%2C%20most%20commonly%20north)),
- across the sky parallel to the [celestial equator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Celestial_equator#:~:text=the%20great%20circle%20of%20the%20imaginary%20celestial%20sphere%20on%20the%20same%20plane%20as%20the%20equator%20of%20Earth) ([hour angle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hour_angle#Relation_with_right_ascension:~:text=the%20dihedral%20angle%20between%20the%20meridian%20plane%20%28containing%20Earth%27s%20axis%20and%20the%20zenith%29%20and%20the%20hour%20circle%20%28containing%20Earth%27s%20axis%20and%20a%20given%20point%20of%20interest%29) and [right ascension](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right_ascension#:~:text=the%20angular%20distance%20of%20a%20particular%20point%20measured%20eastward%20along%20the%20celestial%20equator%20from%20the%20Sun%20at%20the%20March%20equinox%20to%20the%20%28hour%20circle%20of%20the%29%20point%20in%20question%20above%20the%20Earth))
- to and from its lowest and highest [latitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latitude#:~:text=a%20coordinate%20that%20specifies%20the%20north%E2%80%93south%20position%20of%20a%20point%20on%20the%20surface%20of%20the%20Earth), [altitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizontal_coordinate_system#:~:text=the%20angle%20between%20the%20object%20and%20the%20observer%27s%20local%20horizon), and [declination](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_coordinate_systems#:~:text=Celestial%20poles-,Declination,-%28%CE%B4%29).`
```

```{ojs}
md`The Moon takes almost 30 days to complete a turn on its axis but completes all of the other turns listed above in one [tidal day](https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/education/tutorial_tides/tides05_lunarday.html#:~:text=the%20time%20it%20takes%20for%20a%20specific%20site%20on%20the%20Earth%20to%20rotate%20from%20an%20exact%20point%20under%20the%20moon%20to%20the%20same%20point%20under%20the%20moon). To calculate the apparent ground speed of the Sun and the Moon, we divide the equatorial [circumference of the Earth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth%27s_circumference#:~:text=the%20distance%20around%20earth) (40,075,017 m) by a [solar day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_time#:~:text=the%20interval%20between%20two%20successive%20returns%20of%20the%20sun%20to%20the%20local%20meridian) and a [tidal day](https://oceanservice.noaa.gov/education/tutorial_tides/tides05_lunarday.html#:~:text=the%20time%20it%20takes%20for%20a%20specific%20site%20on%20the%20Earth%20to%20rotate%20from%20an%20exact%20point%20under%20the%20moon%20to%20the%20same%20point%20under%20the%20moon) to obtain ${40075.017/100} and ${(40075.017/1.0338635976785888/100).toFixed(5)} m/b, respectively. To learn more about tidal days and their use in the lunar Dec calendar (Decalendar) to measure time on the Moon, check out the [Decalendar notebook](/@dec/al).`
```

```{ojs}
md`In addition to using turns to measure position and speed, we can also use turns to measure apparent size or [angular diameter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angular_diameter#:~:text=an%20angular%20distance%20describing%20how%20large%20a%20sphere%20or%20circle%20appears%20from%20a%20given%20point%20of%20view). The visualization below compares the angular diameters of the Sun (yellow circle on the left) and the Moon (grey circle on the right). The Sun and the Moon appear to be roughly the same size in the sky, because the Sun is about 400 times larger AND about 400 times further than the Moon.
The lunar angular diameter will decrease in the distant future as the Moon moves away from the Earth. Use the slider below to see how [lunar distance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lunar_distance#:~:text=the%20distance%20from%20the%20center%20of%20Earth%20to%20the%20center%20of%20the%20Moon) affects the lunar-solar angular diameter ratio (Moon ${tex`\delta`} / Sun ${tex`\delta`}) over billions of years. `
```

```{ojs}
viewof time2 = {
  const slider = d3.sliderBottom()
    .min(-1)
    .max(3)
    .width(300)
    .ticks(8)
    .handle(
      d3
        .symbol()
        .type(d3.symbolCircle)
        .size(200)()
    )
    .on("onchange", () => svg.dispatch("input"));
  
  const svg = d3.create("svg")
    .attr("viewBox", [-20,-20,340,80])
    .attr("width", 340)
    .attr("height", 80)
    .call(slider);
  
  svg.append("text")
    .text("Billions of Years from Now")
    .attr("x", 40)
    .attr("y", 50)
  
  return Object.defineProperty(
    svg.node(),
    "value", 
    {get: () => slider.value()}
    );
}
```

```{ojs}
// https://observablehq.com/@jhhamer/moon-earth-system
{
  const h = w/4; 
  const sun_radius = h/3;
  
  const earth_r = 3958.76; //miles
  const moon_r = 1079.6; //miles
  const f = 6.29*10**45  //Bills and Ray 1999
  const moon_dist = earth_r*(((f*time2*10**9)*(13/2)+(60.36*6378100)**(13/2))**(2/13))/6378100
  //const moon_dist = (60.36+time2*5.974)*earth_r;
  const moon_angle = Math.atan(moon_r/moon_dist)*3438; //radian to arcmin
  const moon_radius = sun_radius*(moon_angle/15.74);
  
  const svg = d3.select(DOM.svg(w, h));
  
  svg.append("rect")
    .attr("width", "100%")
    .attr("height", "100%")
    .attr("fill", "black");
  
  //Sun
  var sun = svg.append("circle")
    .attr("r", sun_radius)
    .attr("fill", d3.color("#ffff96"))
    .attr("cx", w/3)
    .attr("cy", h/2)
    .attr("id", "sun");
  
  var sun_bottom = svg.append("line")
    .attr("x1", w/3)
    .attr("x2", 2*w/3)
    .attr("y1", h/2+sun_radius-1)
    .attr("y2", h/2+sun_radius-1)
    .attr("stroke", d3.color("#ffff96"))
    .attr("stroke-width", 1);
  
  
  var sun_top = svg.append("line")
    .attr("x1", w/3)
    .attr("x2", 2*w/3)
    .attr("y1", h/2-sun_radius+1)
    .attr("y2", h/2-sun_radius+1)
    .attr("stroke", d3.color("#ffff96"))
    .attr("stroke-width", 1);
  
  //Moon
  var moon = svg.append("circle")
    .attr("r", moon_radius)
    .attr("cx", 2*w/3)
    .attr("cy", h/2)
    .attr("fill", d3.color("lightgray")); 
  
  svg.append("text")
    .text(`Moon δ / Sun δ = ${d3.format(".2f")(moon_radius/sun_radius)}`)
    .attr("y", width / 48)
    .style("font-size", width / 60)
    .style("fill", "white")
    // .attr("x", w/2.38);
    .attr("x", 2.38);
  
  svg.append("text")
    .text(`${d3.format(".2f")(time2)} Billion Years From Now`)
    .attr("y", width / 4.2)
    .style("font-size", width / 60)
    .style("fill", "white")
    // .attr("x", w/2.5);
    .attr("x", 2.5);
  
  return svg.node();
}
```

```{ojs}
md`To make measuring angles in turns more intuitive, we can use our arm's length and hand's width as references. Imagine putting the palms of your hands flat on an imaginary table at shoulder level in front of you and making one full turn to draw an imaginary circle with you in the middle. The radius of this circle (${tex`r`}) is the length of your arm from your shoulder to the tip of your pinky finger.

If you spread your fingers out in a relaxed manner with your thumbs touching, as in the image below, the angular diameter of your hands will be about 1 deciturn (10% of a turn). The solid lines in the image mark deciturns (tenths of a turn), while the dashed lines have a length of ${tex`r`} and width of 5 centiturns (5% of a turn).

An angular diameter of 1 deciturn corresponds to an arc with a length of ${tex`\tau r \over 10`}, which is a tenth of the circle's circumference. To convert between arc lengths and angular diameters, we divide an arc length ${tex`\overset{\frown}{\alpha}`} or multiply an angular diameter ${tex`\delta`} by ${tex`\tau r `}, the circumference of the circle whose radius is the distance from the observer.`
```

```{ojs}
md`Now imagine that there is a decagon inscribed inside this circle. The perimeter of the decagon is ${tex`20r \over 1+\sqrt{5}`} and the length of one of its side is ${tex`\frac{2r}{1+\sqrt{5}}`} or ${tex`\frac{r(\sqrt{5}-1)}{2}`}, which is close to the width of your hands, from one pinky finger to the other. Each of your hands covers ${tex`r \over 1+\sqrt{5}`}, 5% of the decagon's perimeter, 1% for each finger.`
```

```{ojs}
md`The solid lines in the image above are analogous to the major ticks on the clock at the top of this notebook in that they represent deciturns (tenths of a turn), separate our [horizontal plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transverse_plane#:~:text=an%20anatomical%20plane%20that%20divides%20the%20body%20into%20superior%20and%20inferior%20sections) into 10 [golden triangles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golden_triangle_%28mathematics%29#:~:text=an%20isosceles%20triangle,the%20base%20side%3A), and are numbered 0 to 9. The spaces between the fingers in the image are like the minor ticks on the clock, which represent the 9 centiturn increments in between whole number deciturns.`
```

```{ojs}
md`In general, the angular diameter (${tex`\delta`}) of an object is its physical diameter (d) divided by the product of its distance (D) and the number of radians in a turn (${tex`\tau`}):<br>
${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{\text{d}}{\tau\text{D}}\text{turns}`}`
```

```{ojs}
md`To find the angular diameter of the Sun as viewed from Earth, we divide
[the Sun's diameter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun#:~:text=Its%20diameter%20is%20about%201%2C391%2C400%C2%A0km) by ${tex`\tau`} times its average distance, which is about
[1 Astronomical Unit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_unit#:~:text=exactly%20equal%20to-,149%2C597%2C870%2C700%C2%A0m,-.%5B5%5D):<br>
${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{1392684km}{\tau149597870.7km}=${(1392684/(2*Math.PI*149597870.7)).toFixed(6)}\text{ turns}`}`
```

```{ojs}
md`Similarly, we can find the angular diameter of the Moon by plugging in its
[diameter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon#:~:text=its%20diameter%20is%203%2C474%C2%A0km)
and its
[average distance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lunar_distance#:~:text=on%20average%20approximately%20385%2C000%C2%A0km) into the equation:<br>
${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{3474km}{\tau384399km}=${(3474/(2*Math.PI*384399)).toFixed(6)}\text{ turns}`}`
```

```{ojs}
md`The mean solar and lunar angular diameters are both close to 1.5 milliturns (${tex`m\tau`}) or 0.15% of a turn. which is about 50 times larger than 30${tex`\mu\text{tr}`}, the
[angular resolution](https://www.scienceinschool.org/article/2016/sharp-eyes-how-well-can-we-really-see/#:~:text=a%20measure%20of%20the%20smallest%20angle%20between%20two%20points%20that%20are%20perceived%20as%20distinctly%20separate)
of the human eye. Useful references for the limit of human visual perception include 1 millimeters (mm) at a distance of about 5 meters, 1 arcminute (′), and 40 arcseconds (″):<br>
- ${tex`\Large \frac{1mm}{\tau}=${(1/(2*Math.PI*5305)).toFixed(6)} \text{ turns}=${(1e6/(2*Math.PI*5305)).toFixed(0)}\mu\text{tr}`}
- ${tex`\Large 1^′=\frac{1}{60}°=\frac{1}{21600}\text{tr}=\frac{1}{21.6}\text{mtr}=\frac{1}{.0216}\mu \text{tr}`}
- ${tex`\Large 1^″=\frac{1}{3600}°=\frac{1}{1296000}\text{tr}=\frac{1}{1296}\text{mtr}=\frac{1}{1.296}\mu \text{tr}`}`
```

```{ojs}
md`Speaking of reference points, the human hand can be used to estimate angular diameters. If you hold your hand at arm's length (~54cm) in front of your face, your pinky will be about 3 to 4${tex`m\tau`} wide, your thumb will be about 5 to 6${tex`m\tau`} wide, and your other fingers will be about 4 to 5${tex`m\tau`} wide. Measured across [the knuckles at the base of your fingers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finger#:~:text=metacarpophalangeal%20joint%20%28MCP%29%20%E2%80%93%20the%20joint%20at%20the%20base%20of%20the%20finger), the width your whole hand will be about 29${tex`m\tau`}.
- Fingers:
  - ${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{1cm}{\tau54cm}=${(1/(2*Math.PI*54)).toFixed(3)}\text{ turns}`}
  - ${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{1.5cm}{\tau54cm}=${(1.5/(2*Math.PI*54)).toFixed(3)}\text{ turns}`}
  - ${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{2cm}{\tau54cm}=${(2/(2*Math.PI*54)).toFixed(3)}\text{ turns}`}
- Hand with fingers together:
  - ${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{10cm}{\tau54cm}=${(10/(2*Math.PI*54)).toFixed(3)}\text{ turns}`}`
```

```{ojs}
md`The angular diameter of the Sun and the Moon will likely be smaller than the width of pinky fingernail held up at arm's length. More precisely, the Sun and the Moon in the sky will appear to be roughly the same size as a .5cm object at a distance of 54cm. If you want to confirm this, please do so only with the Moon. Looking at the Sun, even with proper eye protection, carries the risk of eye damage.
- Sun
  - ${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{.503cm}{\tau54cm}=${(.503/(2*Math.PI*54)).toFixed(6)}\text{ turns}`}
- Moon:
  - ${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{.488cm}{\tau54cm}=${(.488/(2*Math.PI*54)).toFixed(6)}\text{ turns}`}`
```

```{ojs}
md`The distance from the tip of your thumb to tip of your pointing finger will be about [5 centiturns  (${tex`5c\tau`})](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Turn_%28angle%29#:~:text=in%2C%20e.g.%2C-,centiturns%20%28ctr%29,-%2C%20milliturns%20%28mtr%29%2C%20etc), or 5% of a full turn, at arm's length.
You can use your thumb and pointing finger to determine how far you need to spread your fingers on one hand to approximate 5${tex`c\tau`}. The fact that one hand is 5${tex`c\tau`} wide is easy to remember with the following mnemonic device: each hand has 5 fingers and represents 5${tex`c\tau`}.
- Maximum distance from tip of thumb to tip of pointing finger:
  - ${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{17cm}{\tau54cm}=${(17/(2*Math.PI*54)).toFixed(2)}\text{ turns}`}
- Turn:
  - ${tex`\Large \delta=\frac{339.292cm}{\tau54cm}=${(339.292/(2*Math.PI*54)).toFixed(2)}\text{ turns}`}`
```

```{ojs}
md`Dec uses the [North-East-Down (NED)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axes_conventions#:~:text=North%2C%20East%2C%20Down%20%28NED%29) [reference frame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frame_of_reference#:~:text=an%20abstract%20coordinate%20system%20whose%20origin%2C%20orientation%2C%20and%20scale%20are%20specified%20by%20a%20set%20of%20reference%20points) and the [right-hand rule](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Right-hand_rule#:~:text=a%20convention%20and%20a%20mnemonic%2C%20utilized%20to%20define%20the%20orientation%20of%20axes%20in%20three%2Ddimensional%20space) to define the [sign](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sign_%28mathematics%29#:~:text=property%20of%20being%20either%20positive%2C%20negative%2C%20or%200) of angular measurements. Negative and positive values differentiate between counterclockwise and clockwise turns, years before and after [Year 0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1_BC#:~:text=a%20leap%20year%20starting%20on%20Saturday%20in%20the%20Proleptic%20Gregorian%20calendar), latitudes below and above the Equator, altitudes below and above the horizon, or the time that is remaining and that has passed in the day or the year. The [origins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Origin_%28mathematics%29#:~:text=a%20fixed%20point%20of%20reference%20for%20the%20geometry%20of%20the%20surrounding%20space) and [bounds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Upper_and_lower_bounds#:~:text=A%20set%20with%20an%20upper%20%28respectively%2C%20lower%29%20bound%20is%20said%20to%20be%20bounded%20from%20above%20or%20majorized%5B1%5D%20%28respectively%20bounded%20from%20below%20or%20minorized%29%20by%20that%20bound) of many Dec measurements are summarized in the table below. 

| Measurement  |   Origin       |   Lower  |   Upper  |
|--------------|----------------|----------|----------|
|   [Year](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Year#:~:text=the%20time%20taken%20for%20astronomical%20objects%20to%20complete%20one%20orbit)       |   [Year 0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1_BC#:~:text=a%20leap%20year%20starting%20on%20Saturday%20in%20the%20Proleptic%20Gregorian%20calendar)       |   -∞     |   ∞      |
|   [Day](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Day#:~:text=a%20full%20rotation%20of%20the%20Earth%20with%20respect%20to%20the%20Sun)        |   [Day 0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/March_1#:~:text=the%2060th%20day%20of%20the%20year%20%2861st%20in%20leap%20years%29%20in%20the%20Gregorian%20calendar)        |   0      |   366    |
|   [Zone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_zone#:~:text=an%20area%20which%20observes%20a%20uniform%20standard%20time)       |   [Zone 0](https://observablehq.com/@dec/irc)       |   0      |   1      |
|   [Longitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longitude#:~:text=a%20geographic%20coordinate%20that%20specifies%20the%20east%E2%80%93west%20position%20of%20a%20point)  |   [Meridian 0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/18th_meridian_west#:~:text=a%20line%20of%20longitude%20that%20extends%20from%20the%20North%20Pole%20across%20the%20Arctic%20Ocean%2C%20Greenland%2C%20Iceland%2C%20the%20Atlantic%20Ocean%2C%20the%20Canary%20Islands%2C%20the%20Southern%20Ocean%2C%20and%20Antarctica%20to%20the%20South%20Pole)   |   0      |   1      |
|   [Latitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latitude#:~:text=a%20coordinate%20that%20specifies%20the%20north%E2%80%93south%20position%20of%20a%20point)   |   [The Equator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equator#:~:text=a%20circle%20of%20latitude%20that%20divides%20a%20spheroid%2C%20such%20as%20Earth%2C%20into%20the%20Northern%20and%20Southern%20hemispheres)  |   -0.25  |   0.25   |
|   [Altitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizontal_coordinate_system#:~:text=the%20angle%20between%20the%20object%20and%20the%20observer%27s%20local%20horizon)   |   [The horizon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horizon#:~:text=the%20apparent%20curve%20that%20separates%20the%20surface%20of%20a%20celestial%20body%20from%20its%20sky)  |   0      |   1      |
|   [Azimuth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azimuth#:~:text=the%20angular%20measurement%20in%20a%20spherical%20coordinate%20system%20which%20represents%20the%20horizontal%20angle%20from%20a%20cardinal%20direction%2C%20most%20commonly%20north)    |   [North](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North#:~:text=one%20of%20the%20four%20compass%20points%20or%20cardinal%20directions)        |   0      |   1      |
|   [Heading](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heading_%28navigation%29#:~:text=the%20compass%20direction%20in%20which%20the%20craft%27s%20bow%20or%20nose%20is%20pointed)    |   North        |   0      |   1      |
|   [Bearing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bearing_%28navigation%29#Relative:~:text=the%20angle%20between%20the%20craft%27s%20forward%20direction%20%28heading%29%20and%20the%20location%20of%20another%20object)   |   Heading      |   0      |   1      |
|   [Yaw](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yaw_%28rotation%29#:~:text=a%20movement%20around%20the%20yaw%20axis%20of%20a%20rigid%20body%20that%20changes%20the%20direction%20it%20is%20pointing%2C%20to%20the%20left%20or%20right%20of%20its%20direction%20of%20motion)        |   Heading      |   -∞     |   ∞      |
|   [Pitch](https://simple.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pitch,_yaw,_and_roll#:~:text=pitch-,nose%20up%20or%20tail%20up,-.)      |   The horizon  |   -∞     |   ∞      |
|   [Roll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Degrees_of_freedom_%28mechanics%29#:~:text=Roll%20rotation%3A-,Pivots%20side%20to%20side,-%3B)       |   The horizon  |   -∞     |   ∞      |`
```

The [intercardinal directions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardinal_direction#:~:text=northeast%20%28NE%29%2C%20southeast%20%28SE%29%2C%20southwest%20%28SW%29%2C%20and%20northwest%20%28NW%29) on the compass above are labeled with triple-digit milliturns: 125, 375, 625, and 875.`

```{ojs}
md`[1] The circles for visualizing distortions are taken from [here](https://observablehq.com/@d3/tissots-indicatrix). This is not actually a true implementation of [Tissot's indicatrix](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tissot%27s_indicatrix), which would require to compute partial derivatives of the projection function at the indicated points. Instead, simple circular geometry on the Earth's surface is generated, which serves the purpose of estimating the projection's distortions equally well, IMO.`
```

```{ojs}
circles = {
  const step = 20;
  const circle = d3.geoCircle().center(d => d).radius(step / 6).precision(10);
  const coordinates = [];
  for (let y = -80; y <= 80; y += step) {
    for (let x = -180; x < 180; x += step) {
      // draw only every second circle near poles
      if (Math.abs(y) < 70 || ((x / step) % 2 == 0)) {
        coordinates.push(circle([x, y]).coordinates);
      }
    }
  }
  return {type: "MultiPolygon", coordinates};
}

```

```{ojs}
// https://observablehq.com/@photon-garden/2d-slider
function xySlider(options = {}) {
  const {
    min = 0, max = 1, step = 'any', value = [null, null],
    xmin = min, xmax = max, xstep = step, xvalue = value[0],
    ymin = min, ymax = max, ystep = step, yvalue = value[1],
    theme = theme_default,
  } = options;
  
  const ix = DOM.element('input', {type: 'range', min: xmin, max: xmax, step: xstep, value: xvalue});
  const iy = DOM.element('input', {type: 'range', min: ymin, max: ymax, step: ystep, value: yvalue});
  const controls = {};
  
  const scope = DOM.uid('scope').id;
  const dom = html`
<div class="${scope} xy-picker">
  ${controls.zone = html`<div class=zone>
    ${controls.thumb = html`<div class=thumb>`}
  `}
  ${html`<style>${theme.replace(/:scope\b/g, '.' + scope)}`}
`;
  dom.value = Array(2);
  for(let [k, v] of Object.entries({xmin, xmax, xstep, ymin, ymax, ystep})) dom.style.setProperty(`--${k}`, v);
  
  const updateRange = () => {
    dom.style.setProperty('--x', `${(dom.value[0] - xmin) / (xmax-xmin) * 100}%`);
    dom.style.setProperty('--y', `${(dom.value[1] - ymin) / (ymax-ymin) * 100}%`);
  };
  
  const setValue = (vx, vy) => {
    const [px, py] = dom.value;
    dom.value[0] = vx = (ix.value = vx, ix.valueAsNumber);
    dom.value[1] = vy = (iy.value = vy, iy.valueAsNumber);

    updateRange();
    // Only dispatch if values have changed.
    if(px !== vx || py !== vy) {
      dom.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent('input', {bubbles: true}));
    }
  };
  
  setValue(xvalue, yvalue);
  
  const mouseOffset = (clientX, clientY) => {
    const r = controls.zone.getBoundingClientRect();
    return [
      (clientX - r.left) / r.width,
      (clientY - r.top) / r.height,
    ];
  };
  
  let ov, ot;
  
  const moveTo = (tx, ty) => {
    setValue(
      xmin + (xmax - xmin) * tx,
      ymin + (ymax - ymin) * ty,
    );    
  };
  const moveBy = (tx, ty) => {
    setValue(
      ov[0] + (xmax - xmin) * (tx - ot[0]),
      ov[1] + (ymax - ymin) * (ty - ot[1])
    );    
  };
  
  // Returns client offset object.
  const pointer = e => e.touches ? e.touches[0] : e;
  // Note: Chrome defaults passive for touch events to true.
  const on  = (e, fn) => e.split(' ').map(e => document.addEventListener(e, fn, {passive: false}));
  const off = (e, fn) => e.split(' ').map(e => document.removeEventListener(e, fn, {passive: false}));
  

  const handleDrag = e => {
    e.preventDefault();
    const p = pointer(e);
    const [tx, ty] = mouseOffset(p.clientX, p.clientY);
    e.shiftKey ? moveBy(tx, ty) : moveTo(tx, ty);
  };
  
  const handleDragStop = e => {
    off('mousemove touchmove', handleDrag);
    off('mouseup touchend', handleDragStop);
  };
  invalidation.then(handleDragStop);

  dom.ontouchstart = dom.onmousedown = e => {
    on('mousemove touchmove', handleDrag);
    on('mouseup touchend', handleDragStop);
    e.preventDefault();
    e.stopPropagation();
    ov = dom.value.slice();
    const p = pointer(e);
    ot = mouseOffset(p.clientX, p.clientY);
    if(!e.shiftKey) moveTo(...ot);
  };
  
  return dom;  
}
```

```{ojs}
    var(--gradient) calc(50% / (var(--cols) - 1)) calc(50% / (var(--rows) - 1)) / calc(100% / var(--cols)) calc(100% / var(--rows));

  border-radius: 3px;
  border: 1px inset hsl(0, 0%, 70%);
}

:scope .zone:before,
:scope .zone:after {
  box-sizing: border-box;
  content: "";
  position: absolute;
  background: currentColor;
}
/* vertical */
:scope .zone:before {
  width: 5px;
  height: 100%;
  top: 0;
  left: var(--x);
  transform: translateX(-2.5px);
}
/* horizontal */
:scope .zone:after {
  width: 100%;
  height: 5px;
  top: var(--y);
  left: 0;
  transform: translateY(-2.5px);
}
:scope .thumb {
  box-sizing: border-box;
  position: absolute;
  left: var(--x);
  top: var(--y);
  transform: translate(calc(var(--thumb-size) / -2), calc(var(--thumb-size) / -2));
  width: var(--thumb-size);
  height: var(--thumb-size);
  border-radius: var(--thumb-size);
  z-index: 1;
  background: #eee linear-gradient(0deg, #fff0 50%, #fff9 50%, #fff5);
  border: 1px solid hsl(0,0%,55%);
}
`
```

```{ojs}
function long2turn(degrees = -180, e = 3) {
  // turns: e=0, deciturns: e=1, etc.
  return (((degrees %= 360) < 0 ? degrees + 360 : degrees) + 18) / (360 / 10**e) % 10**e;
```

```{ojs}
function unix2dote(unix, zone, offset = 719468) {
  return [
    (unix ?? Date.now()) / 86400000
    + (zone = zone ?? (10 - Math.round(
        (new Date).getTimezoneOffset() / 144)) % 10
      ) / 10 + offset, zone]
}
```

```{ojs}
function repeat(component, N, initialAngle=0) {
  // NOTE: if component is a function, it will be called with (angle, i)
  if (N <= 0) return "";
  let result = [];
  for (let i = 0; i < N; i++) {
    let angle = (360 / N) * i + initialAngle;
    let el = typeof component === 'function'? component(angle, i) : component;
    result.push(`<g transform="rotate(${angle})">${el}</g>`);
  }
  return result.join("");
}
```

```{ojs}
  `
```

```{ojs}
projection = {
  let proj = selectedProjection;
  if (proj.rotate) proj.rotate([-turn2long(lpg[0]),-turn2degr(lpg[1]),turn2degr(lpg[2])]);
  if (proj.angle) proj.angle(angle);
  // for conic projections
  if (proj.parallels) proj.parallels([phi1, phi2]);
  if (proj.parallel) proj.parallel(phi1);
  if (proj.tilt) proj.tilt(tilt);
  if (proj.distance) proj.distance(distance);
  try {
    if (proj.lobes) proj.lobes(lobes);
  }
  catch (e) {
    // happens for Bogg's interrupted :\
  }
  return proj;
}
```

```{ojs}
function turn2long(turns = 0) {
  return (((turns %= 1000) < 0 ? turns + 1000 : turns)) * .360 - 18;
}
```

```{ojs}
function turn2degr(turns = 0) {
  return (((turns %= 1000) < 0 ? turns + 1000 : turns)) * .360;
}
```

```{ojs}
height = {
  const [[x0, y0], [x1, y1]] = d3.geoPath(projection.fitWidth(width, outline)).bounds(outline);
  const dy = Math.ceil(y1 - y0), l = Math.min(Math.ceil(x1 - x0), dy);
  projection.scale(projection.scale() * (l - 1) / l).precision(0.2);
  return dy;
}
```

```{ojs}
function projectionInput({ name = "", value } = {}) {
  const form = html`<form><select name=i>${projections.map((p) => {
    if (p.category) {
      return Object.assign(html`<option>`, {
        textContent: "====== " + p.category + " ======",
        style: "font-style: italic; font-weight: bold;"
      });
    }
    return Object.assign(html`<option>`, {
      textContent: p.name,
      style: p.highlight ? "font-weight: bold;" : "",
      selected: p.name === value
    });
  })}</select> <i style="font-size:smaller;">${name}</i>`;
  form.onchange = () => form.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent("input"));
  //form.i.selectedIndex = 2;
  form.oninput = () => {
    let proj = projections[form.i.selectedIndex];
    let nextProj = projections[form.i.selectedIndex + 1];
    if (typeof proj.value === "function") {
      proj = proj.value();
    } else if (typeof nextProj.value === "function") {
      proj = nextProj.value();
    } else {
      proj = d3.geoEquirectangular;
    }
    form.value = proj;
    return proj;
  };
  form.oninput();
  return form;
}
```
